subject: RE: [junit] Re: assertEquals
msgSnippet: It is possible that you have a classloader problem.  The classloader is secretly prepended to the fully qualified class name of an object.  This will
messageBody:
It is possible that you have a classloader problem. The classloader is
"secretly" prepended to the fully qualified class name of an object. This
will generally result in an instaceof call returning false. Most
object.equals() methods first do an instance of check and return false if
the objects are not of the same class type.
We have had cases where a JUnit test puts an object on a JMS message
queue, then retrieves it and check it for equality. This test fails when
JUnit's class reloading is turned on, but succeeds when class reloading is
disabled.

Sean

-----Original Message-----
From: benjamin@...
[mailto:benjamin@...]
Sent: Tuesday, October 23, 2001 9:54 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: assertEquals


The message is absolutly right.
copying again from an other run:

junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: Wrong country
expected:<com.notuskey.persistence.whoWhere.CountryPK@e0> but
was:<com.notuskey.persistence.whoWhere.CountryPK@e0>

I don't think it is coming from JUnit though. If I do the following:

System.out.println(aCountry.isIdentical(aJurisdiction.getCountry()));

I got a "false".
The following:
System.out.println(aCountry+ " "+aJurisdiction.getCountry());

I got:
ethenticate/Country:com.notuskey.persistence.whoWhere.CountryPK@e0
ethenticate/Country:com.notuskey.persistence.whoWhere.CountryPK@e0

I wonder if JBoss is not to blame. I'll send them a mail

reference are
